The number of species invasions has been on the rise at least since the beginning of the 1900s. Species are increasingly being moved by humans (on purpose and accidentally). In some cases the invaders are causing drastic changes and damage to their new habitats (e.g.: zebra mussels and the emerald ash borer in the Great Lakes region and the lion fish along the North American Atlantic coast). Some evidence suggests that invasive species are competitive in their new habitats because they are subject to less pathogen disturbance. Others report confounding evidence that occasionally suggest that species-rich communities harbor many native and exotic species simultaneously while some say that diverse ecosystems are more resilient and resist invasive plants and animals. An important question is, "do invasive species cause extinctions?" Many studies cite effects of invasive species on natives, but not extinctions. Invasive species seem to increase local (i.e.: alpha diversity) diversity, which decreases turnover of diversity (i.e.: beta diversity). In the spring of 1800, Napoleon and his troops crossed the Swiss Alps into Italy, aiming to surprise the Austrian armies that had reoccupied the peninsula when Napoleon was still in Egypt.[note 5] After a difficult crossing over the Alps, the French army entered the plains of Northern Italy virtually unopposed. While one French army approached from the north, the Austrians were busy with another stationed in Genoa, which was besieged by a substantial force. The fierce resistance of this French army, under André Masséna, gave the northern striking force precious time to carry out their operations with little interference. After spending several days looking for each other, the two armies finally collided at the Battle of Marengo on June 14. General Melas had a numerical advantage, fielding about 30,000 Austrian soldiers while Napoleon commanded 24,000 French troops. The battle began favorably for the Austrians as their initial attack surprised

The first significant work that expressed scientific theory and knowledge expressly for the laity, in the vernacular, and with the entertainment of readers in mind, was Bernard de Fontenelle's Conversations on the Plurality of Worlds (1686). The book was produced specifically for women with an interest in scientific writing and inspired a variety of similar works. These popular works were written in a discursive style, which was laid out much more clearly for the reader than the complicated articles, treatises, and books published by the academies and scientists. Charles Leadbetter's Astronomy (1727) was advertised as "a Work entirely New" that would include "short and easie [sic] Rules and Astronomical Tables." The first French introduction to Newtonianism and the Principia was Eléments de la philosophie de Newton, published by Voltaire in 1738. The "Bleacher Bums" is a name given to fans, many of whom spend much of the day heckling, who sit in the bleacher section at Wrigley Field. Initially, the group was called "bums" because it referred to a group of fans who were at most games, and since those games were all day games, it was assumed they did not work. Many of those fans were, and are still, students at Chicago area colleges, such as DePaul University, Loyola, Northwestern University, and Illinois-Chicago. A Broadway play, starring Joe Mantegna, Dennis Farina, Dennis Franz, and James Belushi ran for years and was based on a group of Cub fans who frequented the club's games. The group was started in 1967 by dedicated fans Ron Grousl, Tom Nall and "mad bugler" Mike Murphy, who was a sports radio host during mid days on Chicago-based WSCR AM 670 "The Score". Some street trams (streetcars) used conduit third-rail current collection. The third rail was below street level. The tram picked up the current through a plough (U.S. "plow") accessed through a narrow slot in the road. In 1877, Thomas Edison invented the phonograph. Unlike the phonautograph, it was capable of both recording and reproducing sound. Despite the similarity of name, there is no documentary evidence that Edison's phonograph was based on Scott's phonautograph. Edison first tried recording sound on a wax-impregnated paper tape, with the idea of creating a "telephone repeater" analogous to the telegraph repeater he had been working on. Although the visible results made him confident that sound could be physically recorded and reproduced, his notes do not indicate that he actually reproduced sound before his first experiment in which he used tinfoil as a recording medium several months later. The tinfoil was wrapped around a grooved metal cylinder and a sound-vibrated stylus indented the tinfoil while the cylinder was rotated. The recording could be played back immediately. The Scientific American article that introduced the tinfoil phonograph to the public mentioned Marey, Rosapelly and Barlow as well as Scott as creators of devices

Tensions over rising Polish nationalism and the economic effects of the Continental System led to renewed confrontation with Russia. To enforce his blockade, Napoleon launched an invasion of Russia in the summer of 1812. The resulting campaign witnessed the catastrophic collapse of the Grand Army, forcing the French to retreat, as well as leading to the widespread destruction of Russian lands and cities. In 1813, Prussia and Austria joined Russian forces in a Sixth Coalition against France. A chaotic military campaign in Central Europe eventually culminated in a large Allied army defeating Napoleon at the Battle of Leipzig in October. The next year, the Allies invaded France and captured Paris, forcing Napoleon to abdicate in April 1814. He was exiled to the island of Elba. The Bourbons were restored to power and the French lost most of the territories that they had conquered since the Revolution. In the Hesiodic Catalogue of Women, Graecus is presented as the son of Zeus and Pandora II, sister of Hellen the patriarch of Hellenes. Hellen was the son of Deucalion who ruled around Phthia in central Greece. The Parian Chronicle mentions that when Deucalion became king of Phthia, the previously called Graikoi were named Hellenes. Aristotle notes that the Hellenes were related with Grai/Greeks (Meteorologica I.xiv) a native name of a Dorian tribe in Epirus which was used by the Illyrians. He also claims that the great deluge must have occurred in the region around Dodona, where the Selloi dwelt. However, according to the Greek tradition it is more possible that the homeland of the Greeks was originally in central Greece. A modern theory derives the name Greek (Latin Graeci) from Graikos, "inhabitant of Graia/Graea," a town on the coast of Boeotia. In biology, energy is an attribute of all biological systems from the biosphere to the smallest living organism. Within an organism it is responsible for growth and development of a biological cell or an organelle of a biological organism. Energy is thus often said to be stored by cells in the structures of molecules of substances such as carbohydrates (including sugars), lipids, and proteins, which release energy when reacted with oxygen in respiration. In human terms, the human equivalent (H-e) (Human energy conversion) indicates, for a given amount of energy expenditure, the relative quantity of energy needed for human metabolism, assuming an average human energy expenditure of 12,500 kJ per day and a basal metabolic rate of 80 watts. For example, if our bodies run (on average) at 80 watts, then a light bulb running at 100 watts is running at 1.25 human equivalents (100 ÷ 80) i.e. 1.25 H-e. Brazelton held up two stages in the summer of 1878 near Point of Mountain Station approximately 17 mi (27 km) northwest of Tucson. John Clum, of Tombstone, Arizona fame was one of the passengers. In 633 AD, Rashidun Arabs invaded Iran and conquered it by 651 AD, largely converting Iranian people from their indigenous faiths of Manichaeism and Zoroastrianism to Sunni Islam. Arabic replaced Persian as the official language, while Persian remained the language of both ordinary people and of literature. Iran became a major contributor to the Islamic Golden Age, producing many influential scientists, scholars, artists, and thinkers. Establishment of the Safavid Dynasty in 1501, converted the Iranian people from Sunni Islam to Twelver Shia Islam, and made Twelver Shia Islam the official religion of Iran. Safavid conversion of Iran from Sunnism to Shiism marked one of the most important turning points in Iranian and Muslim history. Starting in 1736 under Nader Shah, Iran reached its greatest territorial extent since the Sassanid Empire, briefly possessing what was arguably the most powerful empire at the time. Carolingian art was produced for a small group of figures around the court, and the monasteries and churches they supported. It was dominated by efforts to regain the dignity and classicism of imperial Roman and Byzantine art, but was also influenced by the Insular art of the British Isles. Insular art integrated the energy of Irish Celtic and Anglo-Saxon Germanic styles of ornament with Mediterranean forms such as the book, and established many characteristics of art for the rest of the medieval period. Surviving religious works from the Early Middle Ages are mostly illuminated manuscripts and carved ivories, originally made for metalwork that has since been melted down. Objects in precious metals were the most prestigious form of art, but almost all are lost except for a few crosses such as the Cross of Lothair, several reliquaries, and finds such as the Anglo-Saxon burial at Sutton Hoo and the hoards of Gourdon from Merovingian France, Guarrazar from Visigothic Spain and Nagyszentmiklós near Byzantine

The brief peace in Europe allowed Napoleon to focus on the French colonies abroad. Saint-Domingue had managed to acquire a high level of political autonomy during the Revolutionary Wars, with Toussaint Louverture installing himself as de facto dictator by 1801. Napoleon saw his chance to recuperate the formerly wealthy colony when he signed the Treaty of Amiens. During the Revolution, the National Convention voted to abolish slavery in February 1794. Under the terms of Amiens, however, Napoleon agreed to appease British demands by not abolishing slavery in any colonies where the 1794 decree had never been implemented. The resulting Law of 20 May never applied to colonies like Guadeloupe or Guyane, even though rogue generals and other officials used the pretext of peace as an opportunity to reinstate slavery in some of these places. The works of Virgil almost from the moment of their publication revolutionized Latin poetry. The Eclogues, Georgics, and above all the Aeneid became standard texts in school curricula with which all educated Romans were familiar. Poets following Virgil often refer intertextually to his works to generate meaning in their own poetry. The Augustan poet Ovid parodies the opening lines of the Aeneid in Amores 1.1.1–2, and his summary of the Aeneas story in Book 14 of the Metamorphoses, the so-called "mini-Aeneid", has been viewed as a particularly important example of post-Virgilian response to the epic genre. Lucan's epic, the Bellum Civile has been considered an anti-Virgilian epic, disposing with the divine mechanism, treating historical events, and diverging drastically from Virgilian epic practice. The Flavian poet Statius in his 12-book epic Thebaid engages closely with the poetry of Virgil; in his epilogue he advises his poem not to "rival the divine Aeneid, but follow afar and ever venerate its footsteps." Throughout the history of the South Slavs, the vernacular, literary, and written languages (e.g. Chakavian, Kajkavian, Shtokavian) of the various regions and ethnicities developed and diverged independently. Prior to the 19th century, they were collectively called "Illyric", "Slavic", "Slavonian", "Bosnian", "Dalmatian", "Serbian" or "Croatian". As such, the term Serbo-Croatian was first used by Jacob Grimm in 1824, popularized by the Vienna philologist Jernej Kopitar in the following decades, and accepted by Croatian Zagreb grammarians in 1854 and 1859. At that time, Serb and Croat lands were still part of the Ottoman and Austrian Empires. Officially, the language was called variously Serbo-Croat, Croato-Serbian, Serbian and Croatian, Croatian and Serbian, Serbian or Croatian, Croatian or Serbian. Unofficially, Serbs and Croats typically called the language "Serbian" or "Croatian", respectively, without implying a distinction

By 1959, American observers believed that the Soviet Union would be the first to get a human into space, because of the time needed to prepare for Mercury's first launch. On April 12, 1961, the USSR surprised the world again by launching Yuri Gagarin into a single orbit around the Earth in a craft they called Vostok 1. They dubbed Gagarin the first cosmonaut, roughly translated from Russian and Greek as "sailor of the universe". Although he had the ability to take over manual control of his spacecraft in an emergency by opening an envelope he had in the cabin that contained a code that could be typed into the computer, it was flown in an automatic mode as a precaution; medical science at that time did not know what would happen to a human in the weightlessness of space. Vostok 1 orbited the Earth for 108 minutes and made its reentry over the Soviet Union, with Gagarin ejecting from the spacecraft at 7,000 meters (23,000 ft), and landing

The island of Saint Helena has a total area of 122 km2 (47 sq mi), and is composed largely of rugged terrain of volcanic origin (the last volcanic eruptions occurred about 7 million years ago). Coastal areas are covered in volcanic rock and warmer and drier than the centre. The highest point of the island is Diana's Peak at 818 m (2,684 ft). In 1996 it became the island's first national park. Much of the island is covered by New Zealand flax, a legacy of former industry, but there are some original trees augmented by plantations, including those of the Millennium Forest project which was established in 2002 to replant part of the lost Great Wood and is now managed by the Saint Helena National Trust. When the island was discovered, it was covered with unique indigenous vegetation, including a remarkable cabbage tree

In this order, the causes of the resultant pattern of cup fragments and water spill is easily attributable in terms of the trajectory of the cup, irregularities in its structure, angle of its impact on the floor, etc. However, applying the same event in reverse, it is difficult to explain why the various pieces of the cup should fly up into the human hand and reassemble precisely into the shape of a cup, or why the water should position itself entirely within the cup. On 1 September 1870, the battle opened with the Army of Châlons, with 202 infantry battalions, 80 cavalry squadrons and 564 guns, attacking the surrounding Prussian Third and Meuse Armies totaling 222 infantry battalions, 186 cavalry squadrons and 774 guns. General De Wimpffen, the commander of the French V Corps in reserve, hoped to launch a combined infantry and cavalry attack against the Prussian XI Corps. But by 11:00, Prussian artillery took a toll on the French while more Prussian troops arrived on the battlefield. The French cavalry, commanded by General Marguerite, launched three desperate attacks on the nearby village of Floing where the Prussian XI Corps was concentrated. Marguerite was killed leading the very first charge and the two additional charges led to nothing but heavy losses. By the end of the day, with no hope of breaking out, Napoleon III called off the attacks. The French lost over 17,000 men, killed or wounded, with 21,000 captured. The Canadian football field is 150 yards (137 m) long and 65 yards (59 m) wide with end zones 20 yards (18 m) deep, and goal lines 110 yards (101 m) apart. At each goal line is a set of 40-foot-high (12 m) goalposts, which consist of two uprights joined by an 18 1⁄2-foot-long (5.6 m) crossbar which is 10 feet (3 m) above the goal line. The goalposts may be H-shaped (both posts fixed in the ground) although in the higher-calibre competitions the tuning-fork design (supported by a single curved post behind the goal line, so that each post starts 10 feet (3 m) above the ground) is preferred. In 1939, the Bureau began compiling a custodial detention list with the names of those who would be taken into custody in the event of war with Axis nations. The majority of the names on the list belonged to Issei community leaders, as the FBI investigation built on an existing Naval Intelligence index that had focused on Japanese Americans in Hawaii and the West Coast, but many German and Italian nationals also found their way onto the secret list. Robert Shivers, head of the Honolulu office, obtained permission from Hoover to start detaining those on the list on December 7, 1941, while bombs were still falling over Pearl Harbor. Mass arrests and searches of homes (in most cases conducted without warrants) began a few hours after the attack, and over the next several weeks more than 5,500 Issei men were taken into FBI custody. The deliberate or accidental hybridising of two or more species of closely related animals through captive breeding is a human activity which has been in existence for millennia and has grown in recent times for economic purposes. The number of successful interspecific mammalian hybrids is relatively small, although it has come to be known that there is a significant number of naturally occurring hybrids between forms or regional varieties of a single species.[citation needed] These may form zones of gradation known as clines. Indeed, the distinction between some hitherto distinct species can become clouded once it can be shown that they may not only breed but produce fertile offspring. Some hybrid animals exhibit greater strength and resilience than either parent. This is known as hybrid vigor. The existence of the mule (donkey sire; horse dam) being used widely as a hardy draught animal throughout ancient and modern history is testament to this. Other well known examples are the lion/tiger hybrid, the liger, which is by far the largest big cat

A number of novel ideas about religion developed with the Enlightenment, including Deism and talk of atheism. Deism, according to Thomas Paine, is the simple belief in God the Creator, with no reference to the Bible or any other miraculous source. Instead, the Deist relies solely on personal reason to guide his creed, which was eminently agreeable to many thinkers of the time. Atheism was much discussed, but there were few proponents. Wilson and Reill note that, "In fact, very few enlightened intellectuals, even when they were vocal critics of Christianity, were true atheists. Rather, they were critics of orthodox belief, wedded rather to skepticism, deism, vitalism, or perhaps pantheism." Some followed Pierre Bayle and argued that atheists could indeed be moral men. Many others like Voltaire held that without belief in a God who punishes evil, the moral order of society was undermined. That is, since atheists gave themselves to no Supreme Authority and no law, and had no fear of eternal consequences,

BYU has 21 NCAA varsity teams. Nineteen of these teams played mainly in the Mountain West Conference from its inception in 1999 until the school left that conference in 2011. Prior to that time BYU teams competed in the Western Athletic Conference. All teams are named the "Cougars", and Cosmo the Cougar has been the school's mascot since 1953. The school's fight song is the Cougar Fight Song. Because many of its players serve on full-time missions for two years (men when they're 18, women when 19), BYU athletes are often older on average than other schools' players. The NCAA allows students to serve missions for two years without subtracting that time from their eligibility period. This has caused minor controversy, but is largely recognized as not lending the school any significant advantage, since players receive no athletic and little physical training during their missions.

Of major Canadian cities, St. John's is the foggiest (124 days), windiest (24.3 km/h (15.1 mph) average speed), and cloudiest (1,497 hours of sunshine). St. John's experiences milder temperatures during the winter season in comparison to other Canadian cities, and has the mildest winter for any Canadian city outside of British Columbia. The success of its football team made Notre Dame a household name. The success of Note Dame reflected rising status of Irish Americans and Catholics in the 1920s. Catholics rallied up around the team and listen to the games on the radio, especially when it knocked off the schools that symbolized the Protestant establishment in America — Harvard, Yale, Princeton, and Army. Yet this role as high-profile flagship institution of Catholicism made it an easy target of anti-Catholicism. The most remarkable episode of violence was the clash between Notre Dame students and the Ku Klux Klan in 1924. Nativism and anti-Catholicism, especially when directed towards immigrants, were cornerstones of the KKK's rhetoric, and Notre Dame was seen as a symbol of the threat posed by the Catholic Church. The Klan decided to have a week-long Klavern in South Bend. Clashes with the student body started on March 17, when students, aware of the anti-Catholic animosity, blocked the Klansmen from descending from their trains in the South

Switzerland lies between latitudes 45° and 48° N, and longitudes 5° and 11° E. It contains three basic topographical areas: the Swiss Alps to the south, the Swiss Plateau or Central Plateau, and the Jura mountains on the west. The Alps are a high mountain range running across the central-south of the country, comprising about 60% of the country's total area. The majority of the Swiss population live in the Swiss Plateau. Among the high valleys of the Swiss Alps many glaciers are found, totalling an area of 1,063 square kilometres (410 sq mi). From these originate the headwaters of several major rivers, such as the Rhine, Inn, Ticino and Rhône, which flow in the four cardinal directions into the whole of Europe. Boston has a continental climate with some maritime influence, and using the −3 °C (27 °F) coldest month (January) isotherm, the city lies within the transition zone from a humid subtropical climate (Köppen Cfa) to a humid continental climate (Köppen Dfa), although the suburbs north and west of the city are significantly colder in winter and solidly fall under the latter categorization; the city lies at the transition between USDA plant hardiness zones 6b (most of the city) and 7a (Downtown, South Boston, and East Boston neighborhoods). Summers are typically warm to hot, rainy, and humid, while winters oscillate between periods of cold rain and snow, with cold temperatures. Spring and fall are usually mild, with varying conditions dependent on wind direction and jet stream positioning. As Muslim institutions of higher learning, the madrasa had the legal designation of waqf. In central and eastern Islamic lands, the view that the madrasa, as a charitable endowment, will remain under the control of the donor (and their descendent), resulted in a "spurt" of establishment of madaris in the 11th and 12th centuries. However, in Western Islamic lands, where the Maliki views prohibited donors from controlling their endowment, madaris were not as popular. Unlike the corporate designation of Western institutions of higher learning, the waqf designation seemed to have led to the exclusion of non-orthodox religious subjects such a philosophy and natural science from the curricula. In 1954, major Serbian and Croatian writers, linguists and literary critics, backed by Matica srpska and Matica hrvatska, began to gather for a month-long celebration of the publication of the first Serbian and Croatian books in France. The occasion also contained an international conference on Slavic literature in France. During the conference there were many discussions on the ways in which the Serbian and Croatian literary traditions could serve as a bridge for the European literary project. The most significant among them was the conference held on 14-15th January 1959, in Paris between Srdja Trifunovic, the literary critic and leader of the Slovene Renaissance, and Jadranka Lajeva (later president-designate of the Council of Europe).

The Slovene Renaissance was a political movement and it took an active part in the formation of a new Slovenia. It was strongly in favour of the "cultural autonomy" of Slovenia, its independence from central authority.

Compared to other team sports, the National Football League preseason is very structured. Every NFL team plays exactly four pre-season exhibition games a year, two of which are "home" games (in other words, played in their home stadium) and two which are "away" games. The team in each of the four home "away" games plays the other team the next week and the teams play their "home" and "away" opponents the following week. Each team only plays four pre-season games, but there is a long-term schedule for each team in the preseason and postseason. Each team starts the preseason in the same week it goes onto the field for the regular season. For instance, the Philadelphia Eagles begin the first preseason game on Thursday, April 13, and finish the fourth preseason game on Sunday, April 20.

The 2016 NFL preseason schedule was released on November 27, 2016, and it will likely serve as a reminder of what the teams will be facing next year

To extend and consolidate the dynasty's control in Central Asia, the Kangxi Emperor personally led a series of military campaigns against the Dzungars in the southern part of the steppe. He invaded Afghanistan, seizing Delhi in 112 CE and sending a punitive caravan of elephants and horses to the Dzungars to ask for surrender. When the Dzungars rebuffed the Kangxi, he proceeded to invade Kashgar, in the eastern portion of the region, to crush any resistance the city would raise. The Kangxi Emperor's attacks in Central Asia would be the first of numerous expeditions that would lead to central Asia becoming part of the Han Empire in 221 CE.

The Kangxi Emperor was at heart an ardent Buddhist and he was convinced that his own rule would ensure that the two religious faiths would share in China's governance, and he would be seen as the spiritual father of China. From the 1970s onward, Stuart Hall's pioneering work, along with that of his colleagues Paul Willis, Dick Hebdige, Tony Jefferson, and others, provided the scientific foundations for our awareness of genetic-disease risk and its clinical relevance. These models have proved to be the core of our understanding of inheritance and disease and their application to genomic risk has led to advances in our understanding of many other medical conditions—most notably, cancer. In this volume, the first comprehensive history of cancer, the authors take stock of the field's past, present, and future. It begins with Hall's landmark book, The Mutations of Man (1969), and it continues with the book's successors: cancer (1976) by Hebdige, and oncology and behavioral genetics (1990) by Willis and Jefferson. Mammalian hair, also known as pelage, can vary in color between populations, organisms within a population, and even on the individual organism. In a wide variety of species, including humans, the skin on the head and scalp can be either white or brownish, with dark stripes, black stripes, or mottled markings. In some species, the hair can be entirely white, but in others, the hair is darker, more curly, and very coarse. In a few species a hair may be pink, and in yet others a hair may be white, but the hair may have a white cap, or it may be completely white. As the hairs, or sebaceous glands, (secretory glands that produce, among other substances, sebum), grow out of the skin, some of them may be black, some may be white, and all of them may be either black or white—and this is just the tip of the iceberg! Emotions can motivate social interactions and relationships and therefore are directly related with basic physiology, particularly with the stress systems. This is important because emotions are related to the basic needs of survival and are critical in the control of biological functions such as aggression or anxiety. Since emotions are not regulated by the CNS, these will be influenced by any negative experience experienced, which can have a dramatic effect on brain function. However, the results provided here showed that an increased activation of the ACC and the amygdala correlated with the emotional prosocial actions which were elicited by social stimulation only. These findings highlight the central role of the brain in the emotional and social control mechanisms.

Hegel certainly intends to preserve what he takes to be true of German idealism, in particular Kant's insistence that ethical reason can and does go beyond the individual ethical act, since as Hegel sees it, the possibility of an ideal being depends upon the possibility of an historical being.


What Hegel also wants to say in general is that for him the world of empirical realities is a world of possibility, a world open and accessible to the speculative imagination, a world that has no absolute presupposition. It consists only of empirical possibilities, and consequently, Hegel argues, it is a world of potentiality, of the kind of contingent world that it was for Husserl. For Hegel, the world of this world is not simply an empirical world in which individual agents can interact according to circumstances and circumstances lead to action according to their circumstances. Knowledge, for Popper, was objective, both in the sense that it is objectively true (or truthlike), and also in the sense that it is a generalizable principle (as opposed to a law or rule).

The "knowledge problem" had a significant impact on Popper's views toward the nature of science, as we shall see.

Popper first turned to the problem with A.N. Whitehead's view on natural science, which became The Problems of Philosophy (1923, 1924). Popper began with Whitehead's statement that the science of nature was scientific:

There are only those principles that can be deduced from experience and observation, and experience and observation are, so to speak, universal for the universe. (p. 16)

In the south, in the German-speaking parts of Thuringia, the plains lead up to the Harz mountains, and around the foothills east of the Harz are the Saarland and the Saars. Throughout the 14th century, French kings sought to expand their influence at the expense of the territorial holdings of the nobility. They ran into difficulties when attempting to establish military bases on a permanent basis: an alliance with the Catholic monarchical monarchy of France prevented the French kings from doing as they wished. Eventually, it became apparent that an alliance with the monarchical French government was in their better interest.

In December 1416, King Charles IV gave the French crown a feudal charter, which established the Knights Hospitaller, a knightly military order that would later act as one of the strongest defense forces against the English. The charter's wording made it clear that the new force of the English invaders was to be treated not as legitimate rulers but as vassals. On the battlefield, the French knights were to show "dignity, with the assistance of their arms and equipment" and "render unto these the homage due by any Christian to his sovereign."[3]

The area now called Galicia was first inhabited by humans during the Middle Paleolithic period, and it takes its name from the Gallaeci, Celtiberians who ruled Galicia at the time of the Roman conquest.

Galicia was dominated by the Celtic people during the early 1st and 2nd centuries BC, but they were ultimately defeated by the Romans during the reign of Emperor Hadrian in AD 117.

Galicia remained under Roman domination until the end of the 3rd century AD when the Christian Byzantines took control of the region under the terms of the Treaty of Westphalia of 1477, which gave the Byzantine emperor permanent control of the area.

As anticipated by Nimitz, the Japanese fleet arrived off Midway on 4 June and was spotted by PBY patrol aircraft. Nagumo executed a first turn with one torpedo bomber per plane against Pearl Harbor as bait as he had done in the Battle of Midway. The American carriers lost one aircraft to a surprise attack by two of the Japanese planes; Pearl Harbor, Hawaii and Midway Island and were forced to withdraw from the battle. This made Nimitz's plan a very poor one for this date. The Japanese had no aircraft to fight the American battleships or destroyers in this phase of the conflict, and they had nothing to fight with except the American carriers.

The Battle of the Coral Sea Edit

The Battle of the Coral Sea involved carriers USS Saratoga and USS Yorktown flying in formation against ten Japanese destroyers, torpedo bombers and submarines before they were joined by a contingent of battleships and cruisers. The main event took place off the coast of Borneo

Vladimir had been prince of Novgorod when his father Sviatoslav I died in 972. He was forced to flee to Scandinavia with his mother, whom he married. There, during his early career, he became a prominent general who had numerous victories. In 1053 he defeated the Danish army on the Tanais River, and in 1058 he defeated the forces of King Jorund of Norway. Identity development is a stage in the adolescent life cycle. For most, the search for identity begins in the adolescent years. During these years, adolescents explore and integrate social and emotional resources while taking steps toward forming their sense of self-identity. The process of developing identity during the adolescent years begins with exploring the ways in which other individuals see and treat one's self. These exploring and integrating activities may include, but are not limited to, the following:1) reading about oneself in the media and the peer groups;2) observing other adolescents' self-expression;3) considering the way individuals express, show, and exhibit their feelings, attitudes, and behaviors;4) talking to other young people about one's sexual behaviors and identity or identifying with them; and5) taking part in group activities where there are "norms" for particular behaviors or identities.8 Although many of these activities are part of ongoing exploration and development of identity formation behaviors, they are still "trivial

Athanasius recounts being a student, as well as being educated by the Martyrs of the Great (tenth) and last persecution of Christianity in the sixteenth century. In this period he becomes acquainted and interacts with many other theologians such as Ambrose, Jerome, Augustine, Gregory of Nazianzus and his disciple, Cyril. He writes eloquently and clearly about the nature of the Holy Spirit. To the end his writing serves to demonstrate the depth of His love for mankind and humanity's need for Him but above all to emphasize that it is through God's grace that we are saved.

His spiritual and emotional experiences along with his knowledge of Scripture and the Fathers and a deep love for His Church make Athanasius an unforgettable witness to a time in human history so full of hope in hope.

Egocentrism in adolescents forms a self-conscious desire to feel important in their peer groups and enjoy social acceptance. Unlike the conflicting aspects of a conscious ego, which may lead to a self-destructive self-conceit, adolescents' egocentrism is largely benign, and adolescent egocentrism is generally based on a positive evaluation of their abilities and qualities. The adolescent wants to feel accepted within his peer group and thus feels that he needs to feel "good." Because adolescents are highly aware of their reputation, an adolescent may feel pressured to improve or change his image to improve his reputation among his peers and gain support from those people in his peer group who believe him to be a promising prospect. This pressure to look good to others is often used by adolescents trying to manipulate others for their own gain. Stanley Schachter formulated his theory on the earlier work of a Spanish physician, Gregorio Marañón, who injected patients with epinephrine and then administered nitrous oxide to stimulate them as they regained consciousness.

After the Second World War, Stanley Schachter, now in his forties but at first a PhD student in pharmacology at Johns Hopkins University, began his doctoral studies at Princeton University. For the next 22 years he was a professor there, and in 1974, at age 64, he was awarded his doctorate.

Dr. Schachter says he was influenced by Gregorio Marañón and Greg Morrisett, both at Johns Hopkins, and he is now trying to prove that his theories were more widely accepted than had been assumed. He has published several dozen studies on the subject.

Dr. Marañón died in 1957. Dr. Schachter's studies are now viewed by many in the medical community as providing the most authoritative medical opinion

Hong Taiji's bureaucracy was staffed with many Han Chinese, including many newly surrendered Ming officials. The Manchus' continued dominance was ensured by an alliance with Qing Emperor Kangxi's second son, Li Fu, who was known in his youth as a skilled swordsman on horseback with a sword that could cut through a hundred thousand li. In the ensuing years, Li Fu expanded the Manchus' holdings from Chongqing to Inner Mongolia. He also formed close ties with Tang China's Ming officials.

As a military leader, Li Fu did not necessarily embrace the Manchu-Manchu alliance. He also relied on his men to protect his territory, whether from invading clans or from the imperial government. Li Fu fought both Mongols and Yuan and sought to secure his own authority over all of China. As a result, he was willing to fight the Manchu-Manchu alliance when it suited him. Tech media website CNET gave new Super Slim 4 out of 5 stars ("Excellent"), saying "The Super Slim PlayStation 3 shrinks a powerful gaming machine down to about $250. So long. Long live the PlayStation.

Y DNA studies tend to imply a small number of founders in an old population whose members parted and followed different migration paths. In most Jewish populations, these founder events probably represent, at best, a very small subset of all the Jews. If they did represent a larger fraction (by 50%) of all the Jews, the most ancient Jewish ancestors likely began to appear about 10,000 years ago in Africa, with a substantial fraction of the Jewish gene pool coming from about 100,000 years ago (see Figure 1). This is somewhat less than the age of the first Jewish men from sub-Saharan Africa, so the evidence does not support the picture of a new migration from Africa to Europe and back. However, the new results add to the evidence for an ancient Jewish migration, and they help to eliminate the possibility that the most ancient Jews were a people who began their spread and admixture around the time of the Exodus (12,500 years ago).

In contemporary society, adolescents also face some risks as their sexuality begins to transform. While some of these, such as emotional distress (fear of abuse, isolation) and sexual promiscuity, are often overcome by social and psychological supports, adolescents exposed to abuse by parents, siblings, a babysitter or a peer are more likely to become victimizers themselves to avoid the consequences of having been abused. This includes suicide or attempting suicide (13) and is a potential focus for prevention efforts in communities.

The deeper ancestral demography of Bermuda's population has been obscured by the ethnic homogenisation of the last four centuries. There is effectively no ethnic distinction between the two main groups in Bermuda, the Aboriginals (or Abo), who live in a small number of villages in the north, and the Europeans or Europeans, who are mostly concentrated in the south. These are primarily islanders, who did not settle, and are predominantly descendants of those who first settled here a hundred and fifty years ago. Their land has been taken over by the descendants of those who had settled in the UK (or in the U.S.), or have visited. However, the islands have had very few outsiders for almost two centuries. Bermuda had few Europeans in the 18th century, and not many in the 19th century when the first large wave of Irish arrived. And, it's the British whom we have left all over Bermuda. They have gone back to the motherland, to the London area.

Like the reptiles, birds are primarily uricotelic, that is, their kidneys extract nitrogenous waste from their bloodstream and excrete it as urine.

While uric acid (Na+) does not directly contribute to urinary problems, it does appear to increase the risk of acute kidney injury, a condition that includes severe dehydration, shock and shock that is fatal. The acute kidney injury occurs when the kidneys cannot remove excess wastes, and the urine becomes diluted.

In addition to uric acid, all urate bodies contained in the body are uricotelic. Urate bodies can be made up of four main forms, including amorphous, solid, semisolid and crystalline. The solid component is concentrated and is deposited in the small and large intestine. This is the form that is likely to be ingested in the food chain. This is also the form that would contribute to urinary problems.

During the 1930s, the first two motorways were built across the Land, the A4 motorway as an important east-west connection in central England. A new bridge was constructed across the river at Clifton Hill, allowing for the first trans-Pennine railway. Some 30,000 workers were employed on developing and building the rail system, mainly in and around Manchester, but also in other cities. When Nintendo released the NES in the US, the design styling was deliberately different from that of other game consoles. Nintendo wanted to distinguish its product from those it saw as competitors' inferior products. It is thought that the NES used the same color cartridges as the Famicom in Japan, but made its cartridges black and sold them as novelty items.

The NES was discontinued in the US in 1987 and replaced by the Super NES, which had an 8-bit microprocessor that was significantly faster. Nintendo stopped updating the NES in 1999, leaving the video game system in use for the next several years. The series of games on the NES featured a large family of characters with each one having a distinctive personality. At its peak, there were 12 NES video games in development. All the games were produced during the first few years of the NES' release date, but many of them never made into the final game.

Unlike the Spanish milled dollar the U.S. dollar is based upon a decimal system of values. In addition to the dollar the coinage act of March 4, 1913, requires that United States coins bear a denomination of $5, $10 and $50. The United States did not revalued the currency until 1976, although all foreign denominations are still printed at a rate of $1 per $10 of denominations issued or $0.5 per $1,000 of circulating dies. Thus, silver is much more scarce in the U.S. than in Spain and is worth more as a silver dollar is much more expensive to produce than one produced in silver.

Many modern specialty matches have been devised, with unique winning conditions. The most common of these is the ladder match. In the basic ladder match, the first few players have reached a sufficient level to play a series of games with a relatively high match win percentage. The ladder players play one additional game against their opponents from previous rounds. The winning player is the player who plays through the full series with an adequate victory percentage. The most famous ladder match of all time is the one between a player ranked 400 and 500 and a player ranked 1000. [1]

The final match of a ladder match usually also involves ladder players from previous rounds. The winning player in such a final match can also obtain a trophy. (For a trophy to count, it is also necessary that the winning player has had an equal amount of wins over subsequent matches as the opponent in the preceding match played.)

A true predator can commonly be known as one that kills and eats another living thing. Whereas other types of predator all harm their prey in some way, they all have a purpose. For many of us, having "survival of the fittest" written all over our minds as a form of "natural law," predators have been an integral part of our lives. However, the idea that predators are all about having fun is only half the story.

A predator will only engage in an activity when that makes sense and is in its best interest. The reason that a bear makes "polar bear" sounds is that hunting in bear country is an inefficient use of energy and resources compared to going in and hunting something smaller, less agile, and more vulnerable, such as a fox. Similarly, a hunter will spend more time in their favorite food supply when hunting a rabbit, rather than a bear. The Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo, signed on February 2, 1848, by American diplomat Nicholas Trist and Mexican plenipotentiary Ricardo Sánchez de Santa Anna, laid the foundation for a new Mexican state, the United States of America. It established a provisional government responsible to the United States. The Mexican army and navy were required to remain in Mexican territory and American officials were to administer a constitution based on American law. Both countries took an equally high moral attitude toward territorial disputes, both being committed to the principle that the sovereignty of the state belongs to the sovereign citizen of that state.

The Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo also established the independence of Mexico and promised Mexico $5 million to purchase supplies on American soil, while guaranteeing the United States the right to prosecute its claim. The early and mid-1980s saw economic trouble for Libya; from 1982 to 1986, the country's annual oil revenues dropped from $21 billion to $1.7 billion. At the same time, the country's economy had grown rapidly. Libya's population had soared from 1.5 million at independence in 1951 to 3.9 million at the turn of the century. By the mid-1980s the Libyan government was facing a challenge to its authority as the Soviet Union weakened and the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan, and the Iran-Iraq War, weakened its position. Some analysts have suggested that Libya's decision to purchase nuclear weapons in 1984, and then in 1985 to build a nuclear reactor, constituted a premeditated attempt to gain control over what was to be Iraq's largest source of oil.

From his diagrams of a small number of particles interacting in spacetime, Feynman could then model all of physics in terms of the spins of those particles and he did all of science. A similar story plays out in Einstein's General Theory of Relativity, one that is still widely misunderstood.

At the heart of all of Feynman's accomplishments was the notion that you can model a system from its smallest parts using mathematical concepts that come from physics. He did this so well it is the basis for many of the most important computer simulations, including all of the systems of the quantum world. Feynman is also considered one of the pioneers of quantum computing, but his most defining contribution is the use of maths and physics to model human behaviour. His discovery paved the way for all of the computer simulations that are used to solve the most important problems of today, including weather forecasting, stock and bond trading, and the study of disease.

In late 1203, John attempted to relieve Château Gaillard, which although besieged by Philip was guarding the eastern flank of Normandy. John failed, and he was forced to make a withdrawal through Toulouse. John then moved to Lille in northern France where his forces were defeated by Richard I at the Battle of Dijon on 10 October 1204. A year later, John agreed an alliance with Richard to defeat the English at the battle of Beaumont and then march north.

John and Richard met up at a forest called Villers-sur-Neche in northern France and there negotiated terms for a ceasefire between their forces and a ceasefire on the battlefield. This caused great concern to the English, who feared that Richard's campaign would spill over to Britain. Richard agreed to a truce with John and his forces, and with the help of King John's son, Henry II of England, they began the great Battle of Lincoln on September 20, 1203.

President Truman, symbolizing a broad-based desire for an Eisenhower candidacy for president, again in 1951 pressed him to run for the office as a Democrat, the way the House Republican leadership had once supported him. But Eisenhower was so concerned about the party's continued losses to the Democrats that the offer was immediately withdrawn.

Ike's subsequent refusal to accept a pledge to stand aside and leave the party should a Democrat be nominated for president had much to do with party control of the Senate and with the Democratic control of the House in the 1950s. The final major aspect of identity formation is self-esteem. Self-esteem is defined as one's thoughts and feelings about one's self-concept and one's behavior. A person is self-aware (knowing of his/her own nature, that it is his/her nature to be healthy, a good son or daughter and etc.) when he/she has at least some level of control over his/her feelings and thoughts.

Self-esteem is often described by scientists as a fundamental component in human development. It should be emphasized again that some individuals may have many different feelings about their self-concept. That is, someone may have very low self-esteem and yet have a well-developed self-concept. The "why" of people's feelings and thoughts about themselves is, however, a more complex issue than that. The Montana Territory was formed on April 26, 1864, when the U.S. passed the Organic Act. Schools started forming in the area before November. By 1866, there were 1,907 schools and the number grew to 6,822 in 1870.

By 1870, the Montana Territory had become the second most populous in the United States by population. Its population was at 1,224,081 by 1875. Montana became the sixth state to be admitted to the Union on December 11, 1889. The first school to be built in the territory was at the College to which a new territory was formed. Jean Macfarlane founded the University of California, Berkeley's Institute of Human Development, formerly called the Institute of Child Welfare, in 1927. The Institute was designed to provide research, education and supervision to improve educational and child-rearing practices. Macfarlane was a pioneer of gender studies and a leading proponent of the feminist movement.

Over the decades, the Institute continued to evolve with Macfarlane's passing in 1976, and the Institute's faculty and affiliates became stronger. The Institute's most recent director, the feminist scholar Donna Haraway, received the 1993 Women's Studies Association of America (WSA) National Feminist Award for Lifetime Achievement.

The Institute's research and research projects are designed to advance the understanding among the lay public of gender and human well-being. The Institute publishes a quarterly publication, Social Problems (now published as Social Problems and Gender), which summarizes the most important issues related to gender and social problems.

Usually a Presbyterian church will not have statues of saints, nor the ornate altar more typical of a Roman Catholic church. Instead, one will find a simple altar. The cross is usually not used.

There will be no pews, no chairs, no candles, no incense, and no music. A simple wooden platform with no altar in front of it for incense and singing will suffice while in use as a meeting place.

Bible studies will be permitted in the service. No preaching by any clergy person or any preacher or any hymn at the service is permitted.

The service is usually very short, less than hour.

When the service has been offered, it must be allowed. The time may be spent reading, or listening to speakers or listening to a recitation or the choir, or simply going to the restroom and returning to your seat. As is typical of Protestant services, there will be no sermon unless you are to ask for a sermon

The three dynasties battled for supremacy for over four centuries with heavy losses on both sides. The history of the Mughals, Persian, and Safdarjungs is intertwined with the evolution of Indian art, architecture, literature and music.

The first city was the city of Sogdiana and it came under the jurisdiction of the Gupta king Gajendra. For a brief period, the two other large city in the region, Bhola and Mathura, were ruled by the Gupta kings.

The polyphony of Christian a cappella music began to develop in Europe around the late 15th century, with compositions by Josquin des Prez, Béla Bartók, and Richard Wagner among the most prominent. A cappella music was initially an "armadillo" genre: a particular music style of many different musicians performing in groups of four. Its rapid growth was due, at least in part, to the invention of a vocal microphone, which allowed a greater variety of singers to collaborate to produce greater variety of sounds. The invention of recording equipment became a key aspect of the development of a cappella in the 1960s, and cappella music has remained popular on television and in public places, although it is no longer considered "a sound."

The creation of Israel, and later the birthrate of its Arab majority, brought much hope and change to the Middle East. The British Empire also experienced an economic boom. Although people often think that memory operates like recording equipment, it is not the case. The molecular mechanisms underlying the induction and maintenance of memory are very dynamic and, under the influence of cellular and synaptic changes throughout a lifetime, memory must be reconsolidated and learned with considerable efficiency without any conscious awareness of it. This is what we mean by the word "working memory" or "spatial working memory." Spatial working memory may be used to remember the locations of things in the real world. On occasion, an object is placed near the location of another object or person. However, such a recollection does not necessarily mean that the object had to be at that location or that the location had to be remembered in order to associate it with the object or person. There are thousands of possible ways in which objects can be arranged and spatial working memory needs to be able to discriminate among them.

A common way in which emotions are conceptualized in sociology is in terms of the multidimensional characteristics including cultural or emotional labels (e.g., an emotional stereotype), beliefs (e.g., a cultural view of how human behavior ought to be), practices (e.g., an emotional ritual), and social constructs (e.g., a mental attitude or a social frame). However, different theorists have proposed different conceptualizations of the same phenomenon. For example, some theorists are concerned with the role of the cultural frame (such as stereotyping) while others are interested in the roles of individual and cultural dispositions (such as attributions of blame and blame attribution). More sophisticated conceptualizations are based on a number of conceptual frameworks. The most recent and most influential framework for studying societal processes is termed social structuralism. For a review and discussion of this paradigm, see Miller-Young, 2003, and see also this work by Miller-Young and Van Vleet.

Darwin was hard at work on his "big book" on Natural Selection, when on 18 June 1858 he received a parcel from Wallace, who was then nearly 60 years old. Wallace brought Darwin back into contact with all the world sciences in his home city of Sunderland, Scotland, but not until July 1858 did he arrive in Australia, on the way to meet Darwin at the Barossa Basin in Victoria.

Even though the Barossa Basin was only the third port in Australia after Sydney and Brisbane, Darwin and Wallace were able to spend an unforgettable weekend in September, exploring Australian wildlife, and catching many species of fish, frogs, turtles and other animals while making many detours throughout the bush. Darwin also spent many hours at Wallace's work in Darwin's laboratory.

Early Modern universities initially continued the curriculum and research of the Middle Ages: natural philosophy, logic, medicine, theology, mathematics, astronomy (and astrology), art, music, law, rhetoric, government, and history. Over time, they turned increasingly towards the study of history, in particular that of the Western European and North American periods. The University of Hamburg, for example, was founded in 1100 by King Frederick I Barbarossa the Great (1076-1127), and was the first in Germany to offer a curriculum in Latin. In 1100, there were eleven universities in Germany. Most of these, such as Basel and Tubingen, continued as academic centres of the Middle Ages, retaining their name while they pursued theological or medical studies. However, they also encouraged students to develop their practical skills.

The two major types of nonprofit organization are membership and board-only. A membership organization elects the board and has regular meetings and the power to amend and remove directors, but does not have voting rights on major issues, such as when to cut staff.

A nonprofit board-only association has only members who are also board members and is responsible only for governance. It is not responsible for any operational aspects of the organization. A board-only organization is free from political interference or oversight.

Formal discipline is administered by congregation elders. They then prepare a report, typically titled Disc. 8B, which includes the accused member's personal information and charges against the transgressor. Microbiological culture is a principal tool used to diagnose infectious disease. In a microbial culture, a growth medium is provided for a specific agent. A variety of media including soil, water, and milk are used for different organisms. The media is made to contain the exact chemical composition, temperature, and pH that a number of microbes are able to grow in as defined by their specific requirements. Many different fungi, bacteria, and protozoa can be cultured in the media of a host of organisms. However, microorganisms can be cultured most effectively from the media of any known microorganism as defined by its own growth requirements in standard media.

Milk cultures and milk systems also have their own distinct requirements in terms of media. In a standard milk culture, an appropriate medium is added to water where a specific strain of bacteria or yeast is present. A variety of milk and milk products are cultured in the milk systems. While medieval pageants and festivals such as Corpus Christi were church-sanctioned, Carnival was also a manifestation of medieval folk culture. Many local communities and families held their own pageants, complete with musical and dance performances featuring popular local tunes and chants.

Adolescence marks a rapid change in one's role within a family. Young children tend to assert themselves forcefully, but are unable to demonstrate much influence on their parents' household. It is during this adolescent period that young children begin to be called upon to do more family and household tasks. They are often the objects of ridicule as they are often seen as 'acting up', although many studies suggest that their overactivity in these tasks is not only a physiological response to the stresses and strains of growing up, but is an indication of their intrinsic motivation and intelligence.

Adolescence represents a time of exploration and growth as individuals begin to question boundaries and authority-based norms. When adolescents come into relationships with peers, they also explore the boundaries of their intimate relationships. By this age, boys, who are expected to serve as both a provider and a leader in the family, are able to assert their individuality and set and maintain limits in their relationships with their peers.

The European concept of "race", along with many of the ideas now associated with the term, arose at the time of the scientific revolution, which introduced theories of evolution and biology. By the middle of the 19th century, these ideas were being taken up by the growing social Darwinist movement and formed the basis of race identification. The Space Race was a 20th-century competition between two Cold War rivals, the Soviet Union (USSR) and the United States (US), aimed at developing a reliable and cost-effective means to launch and orbit the nation's astronauts.

In April 1962, the Soviets put cosmonaut Yuri Gagarin, US astronaut Neil Armstrong and Russian cosmonaut Vassily Ivanishin on board the Vostok spacecraft (later renamed Vostok 1), which had reached orbit, and successfully returned to Earth. The achievement, dubbed the greatest technical feat in the history of space exploration, paved the way for further space exploration by the US and the Soviet Union, as well as other countries, in the years and decades to follow.

The Space Race came to a close in October 1971. The US announced the Space Shuttle program, which would carry American astronauts to and from the International Space Station (ISS), a part of the Earth's atmosphere. The first manned Space Shuttle

Successful cultivation of cotton requires a long frost-free period, plenty of sunshine, and a moderate rainfall, usually from 600 to 1,200 mm.

Cotton is grown primarily in two areas of South Asia, India and Pakistan. However, growing countries in Sri Lanka, Bhutan, Myanmar, Malaysia, and Nepal produce 90% of world's cotton. These countries also have very low pesticide use. Pesticides are not banned in some of these countries, but the use of highly toxic and persistent pesticides, in particular at this time of year, which kills the young seedlings, should be discouraged to prevent further contamination of the environment. Furthermore, the sale of pesticides by multinational companies is illegal to prevent possible chemical espionage. Cotton is also grown in a number of countries around the Caribbean and American territories.

Boundaries can be inclusive or exclusive depending on how they are perceived by other people. An exclusive boundary arises, for example, when a person adopts only those aspects of another's experience, while an inclusive boundary includes those aspects of others' experience as well. When two people perceive their own experience as primarily positive, then their boundary will be inclusive. An example of inclusive boundaries are those found in a friendship: friends can share information because they share a positive perspective about life, and as such have common interests. An exclusive boundary, by contrast, arises due to those same individuals having distinctly different perspectives about life. Friends with exclusive boundaries often find it hard to communicate with each other. If one person has a positive, empowering worldview about life, and while another has a more pessimistic outlook, they simply cannot speak with each other without one of them breaking the boundary. In contrast, if two friends have contrasting views, then they are bound to exchange information to ensure they're both thinking about the issues at hand

To maintain a high constant body temperature is energy expensive – mammals therefore need a nutritious and plentiful diet. While the earliest mammals were probably predators, different species of mammals have evolved to find food in different habitats and have adapted to suit the particular diet they find.

Different types of mammals are also distinguished by physical features. For some species the legs and head are used for moving about, while for other species the torso is used to support themselves. However, it is possible for a mammal to have both organs for moving about on land and a more muscular body in water.

Body plans

Head (including eyes and ears) and limbs (typically one footed but also two leged) The torso The abdomen The limbs are then subdivided into an upper body which includes the head, and a lower body which contains and attaches the trunk and legs.

To prevent the risk of out-of-phase supplies mixing, sections of line fed from different feeder stations must be kept strictly isolated. This is especially important in the central distribution system where a single feeder station that feeds to more than one substation may introduce additional out-of-phase supplies.

It is very important that the supply-line segment to the feeders be of the same length and make up at least as much of the total line as the segments of the line into the distribution system.

Note: Some distributors sell a length of line in either half-inch (13.5 mm) or ¾ inch (16 mm) of the correct gauge. However, these are not part of the normal feeder supplies. They are called "half-size" supplies and should not be used in feeder supply applications.

In addition to the classical restaurants, Paris has several other kinds of traditional eating places. The café arrived in Paris in the 17th century, when the city was still a relatively isolated backwater, having a population of less than 5,000 people. Soon, the cottages of the wealthy middle classes began to spring up on the main boulevards, where they were often served by local bakers. With all the cafés in Paris being owned by wealthy families, these bakers became the official owners and soon began catering for all the different kinds of people living in their neighborhoods. The cafés took the place of neighborhood kitchens, and quickly developed into very chic, fashionable places to dine.

In the wake of the Coventry Blitz, there was widespread agitation from the Communist Party over the need for bomb-proof shelters. Many Londoners, especially those living in the area devastated by the Blitz, relied upon the public shelters erected by the local authorities. The London Metropolitan Police's 1st Bomb Disposal Group was dispatched to enforce this requirement and enforce its own bomb regulation policy.

The police believed that public bomb shelters should be located where as much of a threat as possible stood in relation to the building. They made a distinction between those bomb shelters which housed people (for example, hospitals), and public buildings in which the threat of attack was minimal (such as the National Bank in Tottenham Court Road).

Before the early 20th century, treatments for infections were based primarily on medicinal folklore. Mixtures with antimicrobial properties that were used in treatments of infections ranging from respiratory illnesses to tuberculosis were called folk remedies. However, these treatments had no basis in biology.

The first clinical study of antimicrobial properties of essential oils took place in the 1930s, mainly at the NIH Clinical Research Center in Bethesda, Maryland. Most of the studies, which were funded by the federal government, were poorly conducted, and many of the studies contained inaccuracies or contradictions. Nonetheless, there was enough information gathered and published for important guidelines as well as the use of essential oils to be established.

The first published study of the effectiveness of essential oils for the treatment of infections began at the NIH Clinical Research Center in Baltimore, Maryland, by Ethel Dorey and her colleagues. A standard adult football match consists of two periods of 45 minutes each, known as halves. Each half runs continuously, meaning that the clock is not stopped at any point (except when a referee blows the whistle); in a half, the clock starts at the first minute of play. During a half, the game clock also runs continuously, meaning that it does not stop when a player takes a kick or is knocked down. Only at the very end of a half can the clock be stopped. When a player takes a kickoff during the first half of a game, the clock stops for 15 seconds and a free kick (not a touchback) is taken. However, the clock continues to run when the player takes a kickoff in the second half.

During extra time of a football match, the game clock resumes its normal running time when a ball is kick-started at the two-minute mark of extra time. This period is referred to in the competition rules as "regulation time" because the

Communication within peer groups allows adolescents to explore their feelings and identity as well as develop and evaluate their social skills. Peer groups offer members the opportunity to identify with others and develop relationships with peer groups of like-minded people. Peer groups, then, can reinforce the peer group system in which individuals learn more and more skills from their peers through interactions at these social contacts, and as more they come to possess more skills, they progress through the peer group system to increasingly higher social status and influence within the peer group system. If the social skills of the group are weak, the group will not develop enough power to move them into leadership positions within the group.

Social competence as a function of peer group membership includes an understanding how to relate not only to your peers as well as to your supervisor, but also to your bosses, as well as to other organizations. All too often high functioning adults with ADHD who do not participate in peer groups will see opportunities to learn skills they would otherwise have difficulty with

In 1681, in partial repayment of a debt, Charles II of England granted William Penn a charter for what would become the Pennsylvania colony. Despite the loss of the Great Lakes Company, Penn had developed a reputation for sound financial management. Penn ran the business with a tight purse, and he did not borrow money for any major project, preferring to invest in land and buildings. This approach seemed to work as the colony began to prosper. Penn did not anticipate the success of tobacco, however, because in 1680 he had taken the tobacco plant to the West Indies, where it bore fruit without problems. The colonists of Pennsylvania soon grew hungry for more tobacco, and began selling imported tobacco from Africa. The problem was that the Europeans did not get it where they wanted it, and Pennsylvania farmers began to grow more tobacco, resulting in a shortage for both farmers and merchants. Hiberni (Ireland), Pictish (northern Britain) and Britons (southern Britain) tribes, all speaking Insular Celtic, inhabited the region of the ancient British Isles and the island of Ireland throughout the Middle Ages. They include the Brigantians, Barons of Fife (Scotland), the O'Neills of the Isle of Man and the Caraibh (Caribids) of the island of the west coast of Ireland. The tribes that contributed the most languages to Modern Irish were the Druids, the Clanbriths of the Isle of Man, the Ailor of Scotland and a branch of the MacGinty of the south of Ireland.

Many of the insular Celtic tribes were wiped out by successive invasions by the Anglo-Saxons over the course of a few hundred years. Their surviving descendants went into oblivion until, by way of Norman invasion and conquest, they were regathering their strength for final clashes with their new European masters

Allusions to legal issues in To Kill a Mockingbird, particularly in scenes outside of the courtroom, has drawn the attention from legal scholars. Board of Education. "In a sense you could understand why [To Kill a Mockingbird author] To Kill a Mockingbird writer Truman Capote would have thought it pertinent to give us some idea of what was going on in the black community," she said, noting that the novel had been adapted to the screen and would probably be released soon, just after the publication of To Kill a Mockingbird. The idea for a legal treatise was suggested by another of Capote's books, Catch-22. But that book, Goldin noted, was more concerned with political satire.

Sleep does not affect acquisition or recall while one is awake. Therefore, sleep has the greatest effect on memory consolidation. During sleep, the neural connections in the hippocampus grow stronger relative to the areas that are being erased. While learning and recall occur at different times during sleep, one could assume that the consolidation time also varies between learning and recall. If so, sleep could be considered a form of delayed memory. The ability to remember events more than 20 minutes after they occur, in particular, is a hallmark of delayed memory. However, such delayed memory cannot be established via sleep [2], suggesting that sleep has a distinct role in memory processing (Fischl et al., 1983).

The memory processes of sleep vary with the nature and duration of the REM sleep state. Some types of memory need to be studied while others do not, which is why we do not find strong evidence for memory consolidation during sleep in healthy individuals. However, we have investigated both sleep consolidation and sleep-associated memory retrieval

The vast Seleucid Empire was, like Egypt, mostly dominated by a Greco-Macedonian political elite. The Greek population of the entire Greek peninsula, which was to some degree a client area of the Seleucid Empire, was roughly the equivalent to the Greek populations of Egypt and Mesopotamia (in the sense of the Greco-Macedonians). The Seleucid kings who seized power in the 5th century BC, however, did not necessarily succeed. After the destruction of the Seleucid Empire in 539, which involved a decisive Greek victory at the Battle of Issus, the surviving Greek aristocracy was forced to turn to Rome. In the west of the Mediterranean, the Greek state was largely a client region of the Roman dictatorship. The classical cities of Greece, Macedonia, and Asia Minor, including Athens, the birthplace of Plato, had, in the past centuries of Roman imperial rule, absorbed numerous Greco-Macedonian exiles

Plumage is regularly moulted; the standard plumage of a bird that has moulted after breeding is known as the "non-moulted plumage". Thus no bird can be a breeding bird all year round but be "moulted" during breeding season, as it has ceased its reproductive activities and is "moulting" (or resting) during "resting" time. Moulting is also known colloquially as "wintering", as it is also a time when the bird spends the longer periods of time in cold weather, away from sunlight.

Rufous

Rufous is one of the most commonly bred of all birds that are classified as "moulting bird", but it can be found in quite a number of different conditions. Moulting birds are normally considered "wild", as wild birds that have ceased to mate can no longer survive in the wild and will die without ever having bred.

Viking invasions began in the 9th century, followed by more permanent settlements, particularly along the east coast of Ireland, the west coast of modern day Scotland and the southwest coast of Ireland. The main sites in southern and eastern England seem to have been first settled early in the 7th century, in what is now the North East of England. Other Vikings also settled in Scotland, northern Ireland and the Isle of Man, with most of the latter groups settling towards the end of their journey, in the latter case with the help of Welsh traders. The most renowned group was the Jollofar, a Viking party of about 500 who sailed across the North Atlantic in 883. They settled on the western coast of the island, probably on the Isle of Skye. According to a local tradition, they killed and ate a cow that they could see floating between two islands, and they brought the cow back with them.

As cellular metabolism/energy production requires oxygen, potentially damaging (e.g., mutation causing) compounds known as free radicals can form. Most of these free radicals have highly reactive oxygen species (i.e., "OQs"). Other reactive oxygen species (ROXs) are more stable and can cause no damage, but are not as easy to deal with, and can eventually react with the protein, disrupting its function and making it irreparable. Because "good" (oxygen-containing) and "bad" (ROS-containing) molecules can react to form even more free radicals, the potential for damage to a cell increases with each cycle of respiration and with each generation of O 2 ; even in the presence of a high level of O 2.


To protect cellular function during respiratory exchange, the cell requires a "mixed" (i.e., "combined") environment to accommodate the different types of molecules in the environment, both oxygenated and unoxy

In 1905, Lord Curzon split the large province of Bengal into a largely Hindu western half and "Eastern Bengal and Assam", a largely Muslim eastern half. Within Eastern Bengal, "Eastern Hindus" comprised the majority.

In the East, India's Muslim population had risen quickly due to increased migration from Afghanistan. Most of the landmass was considered part of the Indian sub-continent. It was the "new India". The British viewed this vast area as the "land of future wars", and a place to develop colonial influence.

The policy was to divide the population into two divisions, one Indian Hindu, the other Muslim. Both sections were given autonomy and representation in the British Parliament. However, a small percentage in the Eastern half of the province called themselves Indian Muslims.
