The phenomenalist phase of post-Humean empiricism ended by the 1940s, for by that time it had become obvious that statements about physical systems don't have very much to say. The real problem of nature was, in the words of the historian of science Geoffrey West, whether or not the natural sciences were really 'anything like the true scientific endeavor.' These are good words. No one should question what 'the true scientific endeavor' looks like. Nevertheless, it is not difficult to see that, by the close of the Second World War, we were seeing the last of the great discoveries about the natural world. They were all about what we might call 'experimental biology,' which means thinking about and conducting experiments involving living organisms. And to say that post-Humeanas had abandoned the pursuit of experimental biology is to say that they had abandoned their traditional conception of science in general. Perhaps this was the last gasp of the post-Humean era, but it's not clear

The area of modern Zhejiang was outside the major sphere of influence of the Shang civilization during the second millennium BC. Instead, this area was populated by people who were mostly of aboriginal origins—people from eastern Asia—and were therefore culturally and linguistically different.

The "wilderness," as many scholars call it today, had become a place where the most prominent religions and cultures had come into effect. This resulted in the creation of many ethnic-based villages.

The most popular place of worship for most of the time of the Shang dynasty was the temple of the god of thunder, Bau (Bau, pronounced Ba-way). Bau, the son of the god of the wind, was the only god of lightning and storm who is mentioned in all eight books of the Zhuangzi, the foundational work of the Chinese literary tradition. He is also the only deity in the texts to survive to this day – a miracle that would be impossible today.

Predators are often another organism's prey, and likewise prey are often predators. Though blue jays prey on insects, they may in turn be prey to coyotes or even hawks. And as long as there has been light, it will be prey to many other predators. The more we explore the world, the more complex our world becomes and the more we may come to rely on its components rather than the parts. And if the world is more complex, so will be its systems. For each system we can say, 'there's a predator,' and the predator in turn can 'cope' with the prey in our system, and 'cope' with the prey on our system.' This makes sense, even though we normally see the world in terms of these components rather than in terms of the system itself. And of course, the system is all around us, at all times. We're living inside of it, in our bodies, and in the world that surrounds us;

The term "house music" is said to have originated from a Chicago club called The Warehouse, which existed from 1977 to 1983. Clubbers to The Warehouse were often met with a room full of DJs, while their club neighbors were often just hanging on the edge of their room (they were usually playing club music, but the house music they played was often not too different from Club beats). Later, The Warehouse expanded into a larger building at 1631 N Milwaukee Ave. (later known as The Greenhouse), which would eventually become the site of Chicago's legendary 90210 club, which would eventually be renamed after the Warehouse. Other "boom in the house music" clubs from that time, would include The Metro, Elbo Room, The Rock, The Rock Room, The Green Room, The Warehouse, and many more..

Some of these bars had live bands, but most used DJs to play their house music, which was just as popular as dance music in Chicago's urban center

As Western Europe witnessed the formation of new kingdoms, the Eastern Roman Empire remained intact and experienced an economic revival that lasted into the early 7th century. The decline brought about by Christianization and the collapse of the Western Roman Empire after the fall of Constantinople took place mostly after 800 CE; the Eastern Empire was finally subsumed in the Eastern Roman Empire that became a Roman province following the destruction of Constantinople in 1453 CE.

The Eastern Roman Empire also saw the rise of a number of Christian sects, particularly the Monophysite sect, who advocated the subordination of Emperor to Patriarch and called for both Christians and Muslims to remain at peace with one another.

Another place to find the oldest airport in the world is in China, where Hangzhou Jinling Airport was established in 1932. It holds another distinction - it can get extremely cold without air-conditioning, while some airports in Europe and the United States are air-conditioned.

Different phases of digestion take place including: the cephalic phase, gastric phase, and intestinal phase. The cephalic phase occurs at the start of absorption of the carbohydrate, which, in the case of glucose, is in the form of a hydrolyzed and debranched sucrose. The gastric/gastric phase is a period of continuous intestinal transit of the food through the small intestine.

The cephalic phase is an indigestible phase which occurs before gastric emptying. During this phase, the stomach secretes the digestive enzymes into the duodenum. The stomach does not have any direct control over absorption, although, the rate of absorption is increased by a stimulant such as alcohol. The stomach also secretes the pancreatic hormones, glucagon and cholecystokinin, which increase intestinal glucose absorption by stimulating hepatic gluconeogenesis. Species are increasingly being moved by humans (on trade and transportation) and by climate change (such as the retreat of forests in places such as the Amazon, Central America) in a way that creates a domino effect. Other species have already been "diverted" from their native habitats or at the hand of human activities. This has brought both threats and opportunities to these species, and while it can be hard to pinpoint the exact species that have benefited from such moves, the impacts on our biodiversity are evident.

Some street trams (streetcars) used conduit third-rail current collection. The third rail was below street level. The tram picked up the current and used it to power a traction motor with only one or two wheels. The current was drawn back and directed from the tram head, then transmitted to the motor. Many of those streetcars, for example "Auckland's Trams" which ran between the Ponsonby, Queen Street and Queen Street West stations in the early 1960s, were also powered by electric power provided by batteries.

The third rail was also used to charge the batteries of some streetcars. Some stations which did not have any tram sidings could use current for charging the batteries from the main rails. So the electrification of streetcars provided a means to transfer energy from trams to buses.

The works of Virgil almost from the moment of their publication revolutionized Latin poetry. The Eclogues, Georgics, and above all the Aeneid were the literary products of the Renaissance, a social and political upheaval that in its later years was to have profound and far-reaching effects on Europe as a whole. They represented a fundamental break with the previous conception of Latin literature. They also marked a fundamental change of the character of Latin civilization.

A new literary form had appeared: the lyric poem. It consisted of lines of one syllable, repeated until the poet came to a halt, after which the reader was supposed to make a conjecture or to try to give the sense of the story which the poet had set before him. In time of war or state-organization, to give a contemporary example, poets were supposed to be the authors of the national hymns that marked the national festivals. By the early 18th century, the Maratha Kingdom had transformed itself into the Maratha Empire under the rule of the Peshwas (prime ministers). The Marathas ruled India with an iron hand through violence, intimidation, fraud, and even, according to some historians, murder. The Peshwas were often aided by the British, who gave them huge political and financial support.

When the British came to India in 1757, they were looking beyond the Mughals' period of rule. The Maratha Empire was not their primary concern. In 1790, the British were also looking for a land supply to meet their growing demand for opium, a lucrative drug that was vital in trade and medicine. The British were aided by a group of renegade Sepoys who had been recruited by Sir Henry Morton Stanley and provided with arms and explosives. Their leader, the Nawab of Barwar, had already destroyed one city of Bengal and was determined to do it again.

In the months after the Shenyang conference Peng Dehuai went to Beijing several times to brief Mao and Zhou about the heavy casualties suffered by Chinese troops in Burma during the Japanese invasion. Mao wanted nothing to do with Peng, even though that was the position Beijing had taken toward China's other ally, the United States, since World War II. The Chinese people and PLA troops were defeated in Burma and at least a dozen more countries subsequently fell into Japanese hands, as Mao's army pushed on in a series of long victories. Peng Dehuai was so disillusioned with the relationship with the Chinese that in March 1945, when Peng returned to China and asked the Politburo for permission to stay in China to help rebuild the Red Army, there was no reply. In June 1945, Mao told her to get out of China.

By 1959, American observers believed that the Soviet Union would be the first to get a human into space, because of the time needed to prepare for Mercury. This led to two of the more successful American programs: Gemini and Apollo. Gemini had a better success rate, and for good reasons.

What made a successful spacecraft a success? It needed to withstand severe temperatures and pressure as well as the effects that the weightless environment would bring about on the crew. The combination of such factors would push the cabin forward and force the astronaut out of the capsule for an emergency landing, if conditions were just right. Gemini and Apollo both had such systems.

While Gemini and Apollo would do an admirable job of reaching the surface of the moon, Gemini would fall victim to its own success. A total of five astronauts became casualties for the program: William P. Anders, John Glenn, Alan Bean, John Young, and Gordon Cooper.

The name of the island is derived from a diminutive of the Greek word for "beautiful".

The weather conditions during the 18th and 19th centuries are similar to those of that of the modern day.

The deliberate or accidental hybridising of two or more species of closely related animals through captive breeding is a human activity which has been in existence for millennia and has been practised successfully, to the extent where it has become standard practice, throughout the globe [1]. Its modern history dates only to the turn of the twentieth century and has produced approximately 1 million domestic animals, many of them pets, which are exploited through commercial breeding programmes and sold into the retail market, where they are bred into hybrids.

The first commercial hybridisation programme occurred in 1910 in Sweden. During this time more than 3,000 animals were bred in captivity to produce more than 150,000 animals sold throughout Europe, America and beyond. This first programme was based on an idea developed by John Snow, a British zoologist, who was the first to develop the idea that when animals are selectively bred to produce hybrids with no offspring the offspring of most hybrids will be sterile [2].

A number of novel ideas about religion developed with the Enlightenment, including Deism and talk of atheism. Deism, according to Thomas Paine, is the religion that has always been in man's nature—that is to say the religion of God's existence. As long as man believes what he believes, he can act in accordance with his beliefs. For deists, belief means belief. There is no conflict between belief and action, except that if man persists in his belief, he has no means of acting in accordance with it. Deists, like the other Christian denominations, believe in the possibility of a religious paradise or heaven after death. All beliefs that cannot be justified in the face of strong evidence can find place in the Deist paradise. Among the first Christians, deists were often the only Christians.

In this sense, it marked the beginning of a rivalry-driven era. Notre Dame and Navy were no longer simply adversaries, but competitors. This rivalry was built from the air to the football field and was a constant in the decades that followed. The rivalry endured though different presidents and the hiring of different coaches, different teams, different rules and different circumstances.

Switzerland lies between latitudes 45° and 48° N, and longitudes 5° and 11° E. It contains three basic topographical areas: the Alps, the Valais, and the Apennines. The Swiss Alps comprise a total area of more than 70,000 km² (25 thousand miles). Between them the Alps are divided into the Cantons of Bern, Chur and Jura, Switzerland, the Apennines, of Canton Valais proper, and the Apennines of Chur.

The oldest inhabitants of the Alps date to the Paleolithic Age, more than 10,000 years ago, when the Ice Age froze much of the Alps. The Pleistocene Epoch began 1.75 million years ago, when the Ice Age ended. Many of the Alpine glaciers have been retreating since about 5,000 years ago.
